Title: Christianity not Mysterious
Notes: Banned by the Irish Parliament for contradicting the teaching of the Anglican Church. Copies of the book were burnt by the public hangman in Dublin.

Title: Droll Stories
Notes: Banned for obscenity in 1953. The ban was lifted in 1967.

Title: Married Love
Notes: Banned by the Irish Censorship Board for discussing birth control.

Title: And Quiet Flows the Don
Notes: The English translations of Sholokhov's work were banned for "indecency".

Title: Elmer Gantry
Notes: Elmer Gantry was banned in the Irish Free State.

Title: The House of Gold
Notes: The first book to be banned by the Irish Free State for alleged "indecency". Republished in 2013.

Title: A Farewell to Arms
Notes: Suppressed in the Irish Free State.

Title: Marriage and Morals
Notes: Suppressed in the Irish Free State for discussing sex education, birth control and open marriages.

Title: Commonsense and the Child
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State for advocating sex education for adolescents.

Title: The Bulpington of Blup
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.

Title: Brave New World
Notes: Banned in Ireland in 1932, allegedly because of references of sexual promiscuity.

Title: The Work, Wealth and Happiness of Mankind
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.

Title: Men of Good Will
Notes: The English translations of Romains' novel sequence were banned in the Irish Free State.

Title: The Martyr
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.

Title: The Laws of Life
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State for discussing sex education and Calendar-based contraceptive methods – even though The Laws of Life had been granted a Cum permissu superiorum endorsement by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Westminster.

Title: Honourable Estate
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.

Title: I Knock at the Door
Notes: Banned in Ireland.

Title: Dutch Interior
Notes: Banned in Ireland.

Title: The Tailor and Ansty
Notes: Banned by the Irish censors for discussing sexuality in rural Ireland.

Title: Borstal Boy
Notes: Banned in Ireland in 1958. The Irish Censorship of Publications Board was not obliged to reveal its reason but it is believed that it was rejected for its critique of Irish republicanism and the Catholic Church, and its depiction of adolescent sexuality.

Title: The Country Girls
Notes: Banned by Ireland's censorship board in 1960 for its explicit sexual content.

Title: The Lonely Girl (1962)
Notes: Banned in Ireland in 1962 after Archbishop John Charles McQuaid complained personally to Justice Minister Charles Haughey that it "was particularly bad".

Title: The Dark
Notes: Banned in Ireland for obscenity.

Title: My Secret Garden
Notes: Banned in Ireland for its sexual content.
